channel.title: 1994 Hyundai Excel - Electricity dies while driving, then won't start
channel.description:
Hello.
Recently I've been having problems with my Hyundai Excel. I'll be driving, and then the electrics will go (First the stereo will start cutting in and out. Then, when using the singal lights, they go really fast. Then, all electricity dies).
The car will usually remain going (But after a bit it starts to die, pressing the gas peddle causes it to slow down ect ect).
I will park the car and turn it off. Imediatly I'll try turning on the car, but it won't start (Sometimes turns over once, sometimes doesn't).
Here's the weird thing - after about an hour I can start it, and it will drive normally for 10 minutes before this process repeats itself.
I got it towed to a garage, and they found a faulty wire for the command start. They fixed it, and it worked for a day before this started again.
Anyone have any similar problems, and if yes do you know what's wrong with it?

item.title: 1994 Hyundai Excel - Electricity dies while driving, then won't start
item.dc:creator: @vbcoderx vbcoderx
item.description:
@vbcoderx wrote:

Hmm i had a similar problem in my Honda Accord. It was the ignition switch. It turns out it was recalled, and my car was affected, but they didn’t bother to notify me. Replaced it in about 10 minutes with a new one from autozone and all is good now. And i contacted Honda about it, and they reimbursed me since it was recalled.

Read full topic
item.source: 1994 Hyundai Excel - Electricity dies while driving, then won't start

item.title: 1994 Hyundai Excel - Electricity dies while driving, then won't start
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

The belt is either there or it is broken and not there. It’s not like it can silently be ‘bad’ like an alternator. It could be the alternator, and a place like Auto-zone will check it for you for free. It’s also possible it is a really corroded wire, sometimes they will heat up because they can’t handle the current, and the hotter they get the less current they conduct making them hotter and hotter until they melt and/or quit conducting current all together. But chances are, it’s the alternator, have it checked!

Read full topic
item.source: 1994 Hyundai Excel - Electricity dies while driving, then won't start

item.title: 1994 Hyundai Excel - Electricity dies while driving, then won't start
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:4, topic:320023”][quote author=SonGoku link=topic=416480.msg3062969#msg3062969 date=1261000603]

I seem to recall a broken alternator was the cause of a similar problem I had.

Was yours the whole alternator or the belt?
[/quote]
It was the whole thing, had to get it replaced.[/quote]
you accidentally the whole alternator

Read full topic
